Fig. 1 Fig. 2 XRD patterns (A) of the precursor (a) and NiZn-CT samples calcined at 350 °C (b), 450 °C (c), 550 °C (d) and 650 °C (e), respectively. The transformation of biomass to liquid fuels and chemicals is of great interests. Herein, a series of reduced NiZn-CT (CT represents calcination temperature) catalysts with flower-like morphology and uniform particle sizes were prepared by co-precipitation method and used for hydrogenolysis of 5-hydroxymethylfural (HMF) to 2,5-dimethyfuran (DMF). The characterizations evidenced the formation of NiZn alloy phase in the catalysts through the strong metal-support interaction (SMSI), which had high C-O hydrogenolysis ability. The synergy of hydrogenation and C-O hydrogenolysis is essential for HMF to DMF, and we surprisingly found that this synergistic effect can be achieved just by controlling calcination temperature to regulated SMSI between Ni and ZnO. By this way, 99% DMF yield was gained at 180 °C for 4 h under 2 MPa H2 over reduced NiZn-450 catalyst. More importantly, the active centers of this Ni/ZnO catalyst exhibited outstanding stability. There was no significant decrease in activity after reusing 9 times. The current research provided an easy-made catalytic system for HMF hydrogenolysis. Graphical Abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords NiZn alloy Strong metal-support interaction Hydrogenolysis 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural 2,5-Dimethyfuran Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction According to BP Statistical Review of World Energy 2021, fossil energy was still the main resources in the field of energy consumption, accounting for 83.1% [1]. The global economic development relies heavily on fossil resources, which however brings serious problems to the ecological environment, such as the greenhouse gas emission and acid rain. To effectively alleviate the pressure of fossil energy shortage and environment damage, seeking clean and renewable energies is imperative. Biomass, the only renewable organic carbon resource, is considered to be an ideal alternative to fossil resources for fuel and chemical production [2,3]. At present, one of important technology routes is that carbohydrate compounds are firstly separated from biomass by pretreatment, and then converted into a variety of platform compounds, such as furfural (FUR), levulinic acid (LA) and 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), and further converted into high value-added biofuels and chemicals (see Scheme 1) [4,5]. Among various biomass platforms, HMF is suggested as one of the top 10 platform molecules [6–7], but it cannot be directly used as liquid fuel due to high oxygen content. Through hydrogenolysis reaction [8], HMF can be converted to 2,5-dimethyfuran (DMF), which possessed unique physicochemical properties, including high energy density (31.5 MJ/L), high boiling point (92-94 °C), high octane number (RON= 119) and easily blending with gasoline [9,10]. Therefore, DMF is called the “second generation biofuel” [11]. For efficiently catalytic conversion of HMF into DMF, the key challenge is to develop a suitable catalytic system. A lot of efforts have been made on noble metal Ru, Pt and Pd-based catalysts for the hydrogenolysis of HMF. Ru can be used either as an additive or as the active metal [12]. As an additive, Ru was used as a chloride-resisting additive to promote the stability of CuRu/C catalysts and DMF yield was 71% at 220 °C [13]. As the active metal, the reported Ru/C and Ru/CoFe-LDO afforded the high DMF yield (>90%) over 180 °C [14–15]. Although Ru-based catalysts can improve DMF yield, the stability cannot be satisfied due to the deposition of heavy molecules, sintering or leaching of Ru active species. Pd-based catalysts, such as Pd/C, Pd/ZnO and Pd/Fe2O3, have been widely studied to produce DMF from HMF [16–18]. The best performance was achieved using Pd/C catalyst reported by Chatterjee et al. under supercritical conditions [19]. The complete conversion of HMF to DMF in water at 80 °C for 2 h under 10 MPa CO2 and 1 MPa H2. But these Pd-based catalysts usually use formic acid, hydrochloric acid or sulfuric acid as cocatalysts to enhance DMF yield, which inevitably leads to equipment corrosion and pollution [20]. Pt-based catalysts were also popular in recent years, good hydrogenolysis performance have been affirmed over the bimetallic alloy catalysts, such as Pt-Co, Pt-Ni, Pt-Zn and Pt-Cu [21–23]. However, the availability and high price greatly hindered their further industrial application. In the terms of industrial application, developing the low-cost non-noble metal catalyst is highly desirable. Therefore, Cu, Fe, Co and Ni-based catalysts have been tested for the hydrogenolysis of HMF [24,25]. Among them, Ni-based catalysts with higher intrinsic activity for dissociating hydrogen have attracted a lot of attention. However, the Ni metal usually does not provide a high selectivity to DMF due to its high hydrogenation and low hydrogenolysis ability. To obtain high DMF yield, two strategies have been reported. 1) One is introduction of Lewis acid sites into Ni catalysts, where Ni serves as the hydrogenation center and Lewis acid as the C-O hydrogenolysis center, and their combination realizes high DMF production from HMF. For example, an efficient Ni-W2C/AC catalyst was reported by Huang et al. for the hydrogenolysis of HMF and 96% DMF yield was achieved at 180 °C for 3 h under 4 MPa H2 [26]. The results showed that the synergy between Ni and W2C was the key, where Ni offered hydrogenation centers and W2C acted as the Lewis acid, providing C-O hydrogenolysis centers. Kong et al. prepared Ni-Al2O3 catalysts derived from hydrotalcite-like precursor compounds for HMF hydrogenolysis. 91.5% DMF yield was achieved at 180 °C for 4 h under 1.2 MPa H2 and the high selectivity of DMF was attributed to fine modulation of surface metal-acid bifunctional sites [27]. Other supported bifunctional catalysts were also reported, such as Ni/ZrP, Ni/WO3 and Ni/ZSM-5 [28–30]. 2) Another method is addition reducible metal oxide to form a Ni-M alloy, where the metal Ni serves as the hydrogenation center, and the alloy provides the deoxygenation sites due to its affinity for oxygen. For example, Yu et al. studied the hydrogenation of HMF to DMF over Ni2-Fe1/CNT catalyst (10 wt% Ni, Ni/Fe atomic ratio=2) with 91.3% DMF yield at 200 °C for 18 h under 3 MPa H2, the formation of Ni-Fe alloy species was beneficial for the DMF formation [31]. The Fe0.8-Co3.0-Ni1.9/h-BN (Fe/Co/Ni molar ratio=0.8: 3.0: 1.9) catalyst reported by Chen et al. achieved 94.0% DMF yield at 180 °C for 4.5 h under 2 MPa H2 due to the formation of isolated Co and Ni-Fe alloy species on the surface of BN [32]. Przydacz et al. synthesized NiFe alloy catalyst with Fe modified Ni/TiO2 used for HMF hydrogenolysis and a 97% DMF yield was obtained at 220 °C for 3 h under 3 MPa H2 [33]. Luo et al. reported that over NiCu alloy catalyst a maximum DMF yield of 98.7% from HMF hydrogenolysis was obtained at 180 °C under 3.3 MPa H2 in a continuous flow reactor [34]. Recently, Kong et al. reported introducing Zn to Ni-Al2O3 catalyst by reduction of the NiZnAl hydrotalcite-derived NiO-ZnO-Al2O3 mixed oxide. Compared with Ni-Al2O3 catalyst [27], DMF yield improved from 91.5% to 93.6% at 180 °C for 15 h under 1.5 MPa H2. The high DMF yield can be ascribed to the high hydrogenolysis activity from both NiZn alloy and Lewis acidity of support Al2O3 [35]. However, the activity of NiO-ZnO-Al2O3 catalyst gradually declined after using for 4 times and the yield increased only 2.1% compared with Ni-Al2O3. Thus the stability and efficiency of Ni/ZnO catalyst is still needed to enhance. Our previous studies demonstrated that dissociated Ni0 and NiZn alloy were coexistent over Ni/ZnO catalyst and their proportion can be adjusted during preparation [36]. Therefore, through the control of the synergy between metal Ni and NiZn alloy, the catalytic properties of Ni/ZnO for the HMF to DMF may be improved. Herein, a series of Ni/ZnO catalysts were prepared by simple co-precipitation method. And the proportion of Ni0 and NiZn alloy was adjusted by varying the calculation temperature. And their hydrogenolysis of HMF to DMF was evaluated. And the structure, morphology and properties of catalysts were characterized. Reaction conditions (reaction temperature, H2 pressure, catalyst content and solvent), reaction paths and catalyst stability were investigated. The current study demonstrates that the reduced NiZn-CT catalysts (CT represents the calcination temperature) have high efficiency for converting HMF to DMF. 2 Experimental sections 2.1 Materials 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (99.0%), 5-methylfurfural (99.0%), 2,5-dihydroxymethylfuran (98.0%) and 2,5-dimethyfuran (99.0%) were supplied by Aladdin. Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (≥98.0%), Zn(NO3)2·6H2O (≥99.0%), and (NH4)2CO3 (30% NH3 basis (T)) were provided by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts The catalyst was synthesized by co-precipitation method [37]. Typically, a mixed solution of 0.038 mol/L Ni(NO3)2·6H2O with 0.2 mol/L Zn(NO3)2·6H2O and a precipitant solution of 0.5 mol/L (NH4)2CO3 were simultaneously pumped into a beaker containing 1000 mL distilled water under continuous stirring at 60 °C. The pH of reaction system was controlled by adjusting the dropping speed of peristaltic pump (BT50S). A FE20 plus pH meter of Mettler Toledo was used to accurately monitor the pH of the solution, and the pH of solution in the beaker was measured every 5 minutes so as to keep it at 7 during the precipitation process. After dropping, the grass-green precipitate was aged for 2 h; then the precipitate was filtered and washed with distilled water 5 times and dried at 100 °C for 8 h. The obtained solid was used as precursors, which was calcined at 350, 450, 550 and 650 °C for 3 h in air, respectively. The obtained samples were denoted as NiZn-CT, where CT represented the calcination temperature. Before use, the NiZn-CT (1 g) were reduced in a hydrogen stream (0.5 MPa, 30 mL/min) in a fixed-bed reactor at 450 oC for 3 h and then decreased to room temperature. Finally, the samples were passivated with a gas mixture (2% O2/N2). NiO or ZnO samples were prepared with only Ni(NO3)2·6H2O or Zn(NO3)2·6H2O using the same procedure as for NiZn-CT . The monometallic Ni and ZnO catalysts (Ni and Zn nanoparticles) were prepared using the recipe as the reduced NiZn-450 ones. In addition, two reference catalysts were also prepared by the wetness impregnation method with the commercial alumina and activated carbon as supports. The two supports were impregnated by a solution containing desired amount of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O. After the impregnation for 4 h, the samples were dried at 100 °C for 8 h and calcined and reduced at 450 °C for 3 h. The catalysts were denoted as the Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/AC, respectively. 2.3 Characterization of catalysts Thermogravimetry-mass spectrometry (TG-MS) analysis was completed in a TENSOR27 (Bruker, Germany) with an Evolution 16/18 (Setaram, France) analyzer equipped with a OMNIstar (Pierre, Germany) mass spectrometer. The 10 mg sample was loaded and heated from 30 °C to 800 °C under air atmosphere (100 mL/min) at a rate of 10 oC/min. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) were carried on a TP-5080 (Xianquan, China) quartz-tube micro reactor equipped with TCD detector. 100 mg of sample was heated from 30 oC to 900 oC under 10% H2-90% N2 (30 mL/min) at a rate of 10 oC/min. For H2 temperature-programmed desorption (H2-TPD), 100 mg of sample was firstly reduced at 450 °C for 3 h. Then the sample was dropped to 50 °C and purged with He to eliminate the physisorbed H2 at this temperature for 1 h. Finally, the sample was heated from 50 °C to 700 oC at a rate of 10 oC/min. For NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD), 100 mg of sample was firstly reduced at 450 °C for 3 h and then cooled down to 50 °C. Secondly, the sample was saturated with NH3 at 50 °C for 1 h. Subsequently, the sample was purged with He to remove the physisorbed NH3 at 50 °C for 1 h. Finally, the sample was heated to 700 oC at a rate of 10 oC/min. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were performed on a D8 Advance (Bruker, Germany) X-ray powder diffractometer (Cu Kα, λ=1.54187 Å, 40 kV and 40 mA) in a 2θ angle from 5o to 90o and a scanning rate of 0.03o. The textural properties of samples were measured on a ASAP 2020 (Micromeritics, USA) gas adsorption analyzer. The pore volume and pore size were obtained using the BJH methods and the specific surface areas were calculated with the multipoint BET method. Raman spectra was recorded with LabRAM HR Evolution (Jobin Yvon, France) Raman spectrometer using excitation laser source at 532 nm of 10 mW power in range of 200-1800 cm−1. The morphology of reduced NiZn catalysts at different calcined temperatures was observed using scanning electron microscope (SEM) on a JSM-7001F (Bruker, Germany) instrument operated at 30 kV and high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) on a JEM-2010 (JEOL, Japan) instrument at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was recorded on an AXIS ULTRA DLD (Kratos, Britain) spectrometer with Al Kα radiation (1486.6 eV) and a multichannel detector. The binding energies were calibrated with adventitious carbon C 1s at 284.6 eV. Inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) was measured on an iCPA6300 instrument (Thermo Electron, USA). The samples were firstly grinded with an agate mortar. Then, accurately weigh 0.1 g of the grinded sample, and dilute it with 1:1 (v:v) H2SO4 aqueous solution to a 100 mL volumetric flask. Finally, put it into the test bench for testing. 2.4 Hydrogenolysis reaction of HMF Typically, a 50 mL stainless steel autoclave was added with HMF (0.126 g), catalyst (100 mg), internal standard of toluene and reaction solvent (10 mL). The system was exchanged with H2 six times and then reaction were conducted at designed temperature and H2 pressure under stirring. After reaction, the catalyst and product were separated by centrifugation, and the filtrate solution was analyzed by GC and GC-MS. The GC analysis was conducted on a Shimadzu GC-2010 chromatograph equipped with Rtx®-1 capillary column and FID detector. And the GC-MS was performed using a Shimadzu GCMS-QP2010 Plus equipped with Plot-5 capillary column and MS detector. The temperature of injector port and detector was set to 270 °C. The specific heating process is as follows: the temperature of the column box is set to 50 °C for 1 minute; 5 °C/min to 80 °C for 1 minute; 10 °C/min to 150 °C for 1 minute; 20 °C/min to 270 °C for 4 minutes. The conversion and yield were determined by GC using toluene as the internal standard. The recycled catalyst was washed using 2-propanol solvent and dried at 60 °C under vacuum for the next run. The conversion of HMF and yield of DMF were calculated as follows: Conversion ( HMF ) = Moles of HMF reacted Moles of HMF initially used × 100 % Yield ( DMF ) = Moles of DMF produced Moles of HMF initially used × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The characterization of the precursor and calcined NiZn samples To determine the calcination temperature and investigate the thermal decomposition characteristics of catalyst precursors, the TG-MS experiment of precursor was conducted. From Fig. S1a, the maximum weight loss rate was before 350 °C and a slight weight loss was detected over 350 °C, which indicated that the thermal decomposition of precursors was basically completed before 350 °C. Thus, the precursor was calcined above 350 °C. Besides, the TG curve showed a smooth and steep weight loss curve, which accorded with the decomposition characteristics of basic carbonates [38,39]. In addition, from Fig. S1b, there was the only H2O and CO2 signals detected in MS signals, which also confirmed the precursor was composed of basic carbonates. The morphology of NiZn-CT samples calcined at 350 oC, 450 oC, 550 oC and 650 °C was observed by SEM (Fig. 1 ). Fig. 1a (1-2) were the low-magnification SEM images calcined at 350 °C. The SEM images showed that the calcined NiZn-350 sample was composed of regular particles with uniform particle sizes (∼5 μm) and flower-like morphology. Fig. 1a (3) was the high-magnification SEM image of sample calcined at 350 °C. It was observed that the particles were formed by agglomeration of smaller flake-like particles, which formed secondary flower-like microspheres with porous structure characteristics. Fig. 1b were the SEM images of sample calcined at 450 °C. There was no obvious difference from that the calcined NiZn-350 sample in particle sizes and flower-like morphology and the high-magnification SEM image also showed that the particles still have micro-porous structure. Fig. 1c and Fig. 1d were the SEM images of samples calcined at 550 °C and 650 °C, respectively. After calcination at 550 °C, the particle sizes were not significant difference, but the morphology and aggregation state of particles have changed partially, indicating the sintering occurred. After calcination at 650 °C, the particles melted together to form larger particles. The low-magnification SEM images in Fig. 1d (1-2) showed that the particles aggregate obviously. The high-magnification SEM images in Fig. 1d (3) showed that the flake-like particles changed into coral-like particles, indicating the serious sintering. The chemical compositions and textural properties of precursor and calcined NiZn-CT samples were summarized in Table 1 . The Ni/Zn ratios of precursor and calcined NiZn-CT samples were close to their theoretical value of 0.192, as determined from ICP-AES analysis. The BET surface area of precursor was 30.5 m2 g−1. After calcination, the BET surface area, pore volume and pore size first increased and then decreased. After calcination at 350 °C, the BET surface area increased from 30.5 m2 g−1 of precursor to 62.9 m2 g−1. The increase was due to the great change of the sample structure after calcination. With the increase of temperature, the precursor was decomposed to generate a large amount of H2O and CO2, resulting in pore volume and pore size from 0.12 cm3 g−1 and 15.1 nm to 0.30 cm3 g−1 and 19.2 nm, and the surface area of the calcined sample also increased. Increasing calcination temperature to 450 °C, both of the BET surface area and pore volume of NiZn-450 decreased, but the pore size increased from 19.2 to 40.8 nm, which indicated that the stacking of particles have changed significantly. Further increasing calcination temperature (550 and 650 °C) caused the obvious decrease in BET surface area and pore volume, indicating that the sintering of samples has occurred. Fig. 2 showed the XRD patterns of the precursor and calcined samples. For the precursor in Fig. 2A(a), peaks at 13.1o, 28.3o, 32.9o, 36.2o and 24.3o, 34.9o, 59.9o were referred to diffraction peaks of basic zinc carbonate and basic nickel carbonate, respectively (xZnCO3·yZn(OH)·zH2O, PDF#19-1458 and xNiCO3·yNi(OH)·zH2O, PDF#35-0501) [40]. After calcination for all calcined samples in Fig 2A(b-e), diffraction peaks at 31.4o, 34.4o, 36.3o, 47.5o, 56.6o, 62.9o and 67.9o appeared, which belong to hexagonal ZnO (PDF#36-1451). There was no diffraction peak of basic carbonates, indicating the full decomposition structures after calcination above 350 °C. This result was confirmed by the TG-MS characterization. Except for the characteristic diffraction peaks of ZnO, only one weak and wide diffraction peak appeared at about 2θ=43.0o, which was attributed to NiO in calcined NiZn-350 and NiZn-450 samples, as shown in Fig. 2A(b-c), indicating that the formed NiO were small and highly dispersed. Further elevation of calcination temperature to 550 and 650 °C, the diffraction peaks of NiZn-550 and NiZn-650 samples in Fig. 2A(d-e) become narrower and higher, and a new NiO peak appeared at about 2θ=37.0o, which indicated that the sample particles grow up obviously. Based on the half-peak width of the diffraction peaks at 2θ=36.3o and 2θ=43.0o, the crystal sizes of ZnO and NiO in calcined NiZn-CT samples were calculated using the Scherrer equation [41]. The crystal sizes of ZnO were 11.5, 18.1, 32.7 and 45.2 nm, respectively, and the crystal sizes of NiO were 7.2, 9.6, 18.8 and 27.5 nm, respectively, for samples calcined at 350, 450, 550 and 650 °C (Table 1). The above results showed that when the calcination temperature was low (350 oC and 450 °C), the crystal sizes were small, but when the temperature was high (550 °C and 650 °C), the sample crystals increased sharply mainly due to the sintering at high temperature, as evidenced in BET results (Table 1). XRD patterns of the calcined samples at 2θ=37o-45o were enlarged in Fig. 2B to observe the fine structure of NiO species. The pink lines at the bottom indicate the characteristic peaks of NiO crystal (PDF#47-1049). Compared with NiO, all samples exhibited a shift to lower angles, which was characteristic of a lager unit cell. The enlargement of the lattice was attributed to Zn doping into NiO by the strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) [42]. And it became more intensive when calcination temperature increased from 350 °C to 650 °C, as a result, the diffraction peaks of NiO shifted to lower angles. The shift indicated that elevating calcination temperature can increase the proportion of Zn penetrating in NiO lattice due to strong metal-support interaction. Raman spectra of calcined NiZn-CT samples was conducted and results were shown in Fig. 3 . Raman bands at 380 cm−1, 720 cm−1 and 1060 cm−1 in Fig. 3a were related to vibrations of the basic carbonate (Ni and Zn) structure. The bands disappeared after calcination at 350 °C, indicating that the basic carbonate structure of precursor completely decomposed. As reported in previous studies [43], crystalline NiO exhibited a characteristic band at about 500 cm−1 and crystalline ZnO exhibited several bands at 330 cm−1, 380 cm−1, 440 cm−1 and 1140 cm−1, respectively. For sample calcined at 350 °C, only one band at about 500 cm−1 was observed, corresponding to crystalline NiO. By raising the calcination temperature to 450 °C, additional peak (440 cm−1) corresponding to crystalline ZnO was observed. Further elevating the temperature to 550 and 650 oC, other characteristic bands of crystalline ZnO also observed, which indicated the particle sizes of ZnO gradually increased with the calcination temperature. In addition, a band around 550 cm−1 was observed with the increase of calcination temperature, which was different from the Raman bands of crystalline NiO and ZnO. According to the related literature [44], the band at 550 cm−1 was attributed to the results of the strong interaction between metal and support. The above results showed that the particles grow up and the interaction between NiO and ZnO increased with the increase of calcination temperature. To investigate the reducibility of samples and the interaction between NiO and ZnO, H2-TPR experiments were conducted (Fig. 4 ). In Fig. 4a, there was no obvious H2 consumption signal of ZnO observed for pure ZnO sample, indicating that it was hard for ZnO to be reduced by H2 [45]. In Fig. 4b, a sharp and asymmetric reduction peak for pure NiO was observed at about 380 °C, meaning that the particle sizes of NiO were non-uniform. In Fig. 4c-f, the reduction peaks of NiO in NiZn-CT samples presented better symmetry, indicating that the addition of ZnO promoted the uniform distribution of NiO particles by co-precipitation method. In Fig. 4c, NiZn-350 sample exhibited two hydrogen consumption peaks, illustrating the existence of two different Ni species. The first peak at about 220 °C was the reduction of free NiO species and the main reduction peak at about 395 oC was ascribed to the reduction of NiO in the interaction with ZnO. The NiZn-CT samples in Fig. 4d-f calcined at higher temperature (450 oC, 550 °C and 650 °C) all exhibited similar reduction profiles and the main reduction peak shifted from 408 °C to 460 °C, indicating that the reduction of NiO was more difficult. This may be caused by two reasons: 1) increasing calcination temperature leads to the enhancement of interaction between Ni and ZnO; 2) the higher calcination temperature leads to the growth and even sintering of NiO particles, as revealed by the XRD results. To completely reduce NiO to Ni0, calcined NiZn-CT samples were reduced at 450 °C in this work. In addition, the tail peak signals for NiZn-CT samples between 500 and 800 °C can be attributed to the reduction of ZnO [46]. The Zn2+ reduction to Zn0 in the NiZn-CT samples was facilitated by the addition of Ni. On the one hand, H2 is easily activated on metal Ni, which can spill-over to ZnO surface, on the other hand, NiZn alloy can stabilize the metallic Zn [47]. Therefore, ZnO can be reduced with the assistance of Ni to form NiZn alloy. 3.2 The characterization of the reduced NiZn-CT catalysts For determination of the structure of the reduced NiZn-CT catalysts, XRD were carried out and the patterns was shown in Fig. 5 . As the comparison, XRD of Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/AC samples reduced at 450 °C were conducted also (Fig. S2). From Fig S2, Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/AC samples exhibited same diffraction peaks at 44.5o and 51.8° corresponding to the metallic Ni (PDF#04-0850). For the reduced NiZn-CT samples, all the Ni characteristic peaks shifted to lower angles (Fig. 5A), which was proposed as the inclusion of Zn into the Ni lattice by the strong metal-support interaction [48]. And a new diffraction peak appeared at 46.8o which corresponded to NiZn alloy (PDF#06-0672), suggesting the formation of Ni-Zn (Ni1-x-Znx) structure. For further deduction of the fine structure of Ni species, XRD patterns of reduced NiZn-CT samples at 2θ=43o-53o were shown in Fig. 5B. From Fig. 5B, it was founded that the peaks (2θ=43.5o) of NiZn gradually intensified and shifted to lower angles with the increase of calcination temperature, which indicated that the elevation of calcination temperature can increase proportion of Zn inclusion to Ni lattice to form NiZn alloys. Thus, we can adjust the amount of NiZn alloy by the change of calcination temperature. However, too high calcination temperature will inevitably lead to sintering of catalysts. Therefore, it was very important to select an appropriate calcination temperature to effectively improve the reaction performance of the catalyst. The SEM images of the reduced NiZn-CT (CT=350 °C, 450 °C, 550 °C and 650 °C) catalysts were showed in Fig. S3. Compared with the calcined NiZn-CT samples, the particle sizes and morphology of reduced catalysts have no obvious difference, which indicated that the morphology of the catalysts can be basically maintained after the H2 reduction treatment at 450 °C. To investigate the geometric properties of Ni species in reduced NiZn-CT samples, the characterization of HRTEM was conducted (Fig. 6 ). Fig. 6a showed a HRTEM image of the selected area in reduced NiZn-350 sample, the particle size of Ni species was about 10 nm. And Ni particle was overlapped by the ZnO layer with clear lattice fringes. A similar phenomenon has also been reported in the Pd/FeOx and Ni/ZnO catalyst system after a higher reduction temperature, indicating the occurrence of the SMSI state [49]. With the increase calcined temperature from 350 °C to 550 °C (Fig. 6b-c), the lattice fringes of overlapped ZnO become vague and a poor crystallized ZnO layer can be observed around the Ni particles. This supported that Zn was introduced to Ni lattice. Further increasing calcination temperature to 650 °C (Fig. 6d), the formation of new lattice fringes can be observed due to the rearrangement of the interface between Ni and Zn particles. The new lattice was corresponding to NiZn alloy. The above results showed that NiZn alloy was formed due to strong metal-support interaction and the proportion of Zn and Ni increased with the elevation of calcination temperature. To further investigate the electronic properties of the reduced NiZn-CT catalysts, the XPS technique was employed (Fig. 7 ). In Ni 2p, the major peaks at about 852.4 and 857.6 eV are attributed to the Ni metal (Ni0) and the peaks at about 855.8 and 861.6 eV are the characteristic peaks of Ni2+ in NiO. In Zn 2p, the peaks at about 1021.3 eV and 1044.4 eV are the characteristic peaks of Zn2+ in ZnO [50]. Wang et al. [36] has confirmed that the electron-rich state on the surfaces of Ni atoms came from ionized vacancies (Vo•) in ZnO lattices, which gave electrons to Ni generating SMSI state. In this work, with the increase of calcined temperature from 350 °C to 650 °C, the binding energies of Ni0 negatively shifted about 0.3 eV. Besides, from Zn 2p in Fig. S4, the binding energies of Zn positively shifted about 0.2 eV, which indicated that the vacancies (Vo•) in ZnO lattices gave more electrons to Ni atoms with the elevation of calcination temperature. And stronger interaction was formed between Ni and ZnO. NH3-TPD characterization was conducted to reveal the acidity properties of the reduced NiZn-CT catalysts, as well as those of Ni/AC and Ni/Al2O3 reference catalysts. From Fig.8 (a-b), the main peak appeared about 120 °C for Ni/AC and Ni/Al2O3, which could be attributed to the weak Lewis acid sites [27]. According to the previous reports [29], Lewis acid sites were crucial for C-O hydrogenolysis of HMF. However, NiZn-CT samples did not show any NH3 desorption peak (Fig. 8(c-f)), indicating there was almost no Lewis acid sites. If these catalysts did not have Lewis acid sites, how C-O bond can be hydrogenolyzed? This problem will be addressed in the later experiment sections. The SEM observation showed that the reduced NiZn-CT samples prepared by simple co-precipitation method featured flower-like morphology and uniform particle sizes. H2-TPR and Raman spectra revealed that the strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) state was generated by calcination and strengthened by the increasing calcination temperature. XRD, TEM and XPS characterizations evidenced that Zn can be introduced to Ni lattice to form NiZn alloy after reduction and the proportion of NiZn alloy increased with the elevation of calcination temperature, which can bring the positive effect on the selective hydrogenolysis of HMF to DMF as shown in the following experiment. However, the increase of calcination temperature inevitably results in sintering of catalyst, which makes the particle sizes larger and the specific surface area smaller, as revealed by the XRD, BET and SEM. These situations may bring the detrimental effect on the catalytic reaction. Thus, the moderate adjusting the NiZn catalytic system was crucial. 3.3 Hydrogenolysis reaction of HMF Hydrogenolysis reaction of HMF over various catalysts was conducted at 180 °C for 4 h under 2 MPa H2. The products were qualitatively analyzed by the GC-MS. It showed that expect for the target product DMF, several byproducts were formed also, including 5-methyfurfural (5-MF), 2,5-dihydroxymethylfuran (DHMF) and etherification compound (EF) between HMF and 2-propanol. When no catalyst adding or with calcined NiZn-350 sample as catalyst, the reaction was basically not occurred (Table 2 , Entries 1-2). When the 350 °C calcined sample reduced at 450 °C for 3 h (Table 2, Entry 3), the yield of DMF was 87.6%. 5-MF and EF were the main byproducts with 7.5% and 1.3% yields respectively, and the trace DHMF (0.5%) was observed, which may be the result of the low C-O hydrogenolysis ability of reduced NiZn-350 catalyst. When the reduced NiZn-450 catalyst was used (Table 2, Entry 4), the yield of DMF was reached up to 99% and 5-MF, EF and DHMF were all disappeared, which indicated that the elevation of calcination temperature to 450 °C can significantly improve the C-O hydrogenolysis ability of the catalyst. When the reduced NiZn-550 catalyst was used (Table 2, Entry 5), the conversion of HMF decreased to 95% and yield of DMF decreased to 73.1%. When the reduced NiZn-650 catalyst was used (Table 2, Entry 6), the conversion of HMF further decreased to 88% and yield of DMF was only 41%. And 5-MF was the main byproduct with 17.5% and 49.3% yields respectively, which indicated that the hydrogenation ability of the catalyst decreased with further increasing calcination temperature above 450 °C. The characterizations have confirmed that the NiZn alloy was formed and the proportion increased with the elevation of calcination temperature. At a lower calcination temperature (350 °C), the amount of NiZn alloy was low, which lead the catalyst to showing low C-O hydrogenolysis ability but high hydrogenation ability. At a higher calcination temperature (550 °C or 650 °C), the amount of NiZn alloy was high, which render the catalyst to exhibit high C-O hydrogenolysis ability. However, too high calcination temperature inevitably caused catalyst sintering, which decreased the hydrogenation ability of the catalyst. It was proposed that the appropriate calcination temperature can give rise to an appropriate SMSI (not too weak and not too strong) and appropriate amount of NiZn alloy in NiZn catalytic system, which can achieved the hydrogenolysis of HMF with high efficiency. And we also found that the hydrogenation and C-O hydrogenolysis ability can be easily controlled only by adjusting the calcination temperature. The reaction of HMF to DMF needs the good matching of C=O hydrogenation and C-O hydrogenolysis. To understand the contribution of each metal in NiZn system, and investigate the synergistic effect between Ni and Zn. Metal Ni, ZnO and physical mixture of them were used catalysts for HMF hydrogenolysis reaction (Table 2, Entries 7-9). When metal Ni was used, only 15.3% DMF yield was obtained at the 71.5% conversion of HMF. Notably, the hydrogenated compound of DHMF was detected as the main product, indicating that good hydrogenation ability but poor C-O hydrogenolysis ability of metal Ni catalyst. When ZnO was used, the reaction was not occurred. When physical mixture of metal Ni and ZnO was used as catalyst, the conversion of HMF and yield of DMF hardly changed compared with the Ni catalyst, indicating the poor C-O hydrogenolysis ability of ZnO. This is due to the less Lewis acid sites in ZnO. However, when reduced NiZn-450 catalyst was used, 99% DMF yield was obtained at the 100% conversion of HMF. The above results illustrated that there was the good synergistic effect between Ni and ZnO by forming NiZn alloy, and Ni was the hydrogenation center and NiZn alloy was the C-O hydrogenolysis center. This phenomenon has not been reported in previous reports. In addition, two traditionally monometallic catalysts Ni/AC, Ni/Al2O3 and two good bimetallic catalysts (7Ni-30W2C/AC and Ni/LaFeO3) reported in the literatures [26,51] were compared (Table 2, Entries 10-13). The results showed that the reduced NiZn-450 catalyst in this work presented the best performance. To reveal the active center of reduced NiZn-CT catalysts for HMF hydrogenolysis reaction, H2 temperature-programmed desorption (H2-TPD) was used [52]. From Fig. 9 , there were two H2 desorption peaks, one at low temperature about 220 °C and another at high temperature about 300 °C, suggesting two types of active centers. Under a low calcination temperature (350 °C), the amount of the low-temperature active center was high, but the amount of the high-temperature active center was low. From above Figs. 2 and 3, it can be seen that the interaction between Ni and ZnO is week after 350 °C calcination, leading to most of nickel existed in the form of Ni0 which provided the low-temperature active center and small amount of nickel existed in the form of NiZn alloy which formed the high-temperature active center. With the elevation of calcination temperature from 350 °C to 650 °C, the amount of low-temperature active center decreased gradually, while the amount high-temperature active center increased gradually, and the peak position moved to a higher temperature. From Figs. 5 and 6, it can be seen that the amount of NiZn alloy increased with increasing the calcination temperature. This variation tendency also suggested that the high temperature active center corresponds to the NiZn alloy. When the catalyst calcinated at 450 °C, appropriate amounts of hydrogenation centers from metal Ni and C-O hydrogenolysis center from NiZn alloy were obtained, making the reduced NiZn catalyst showed excellent catalytic performance for HMF hydrogenolysis. The experiment involved the optimization of reaction conditions over reduced NiZn-450 catalyst (reaction temperature, H2 pressure, catalyst content and solvent) were conducted and the results were shown in Fig 10 . It can be seen that the complete conversion of HMF could be achieved at 170 °C (Fig. 10a). With the increase of reaction temperature from 160 oC to 180 oC, the yield of DMF increased from 31.5% to 99% and then slightly decreased with further increasing reaction temperature to 190 oC (97.5%) and 200 oC (96.1%). Thus 180 °C was chosen as the optimal reaction temperature. It was observed from Fig. 10b, increasing H2 pressure from 0.5 MPa to 2.0 MPa significantly improved the yield of DMF from 39.8% to 99%, but further increasing H2 pressure to 2.5 MPa, the yield of DMF was maintained, which indicated that the hydrogen pressure of 2.0 MPa was sufficient. When increasing catalyst content from 30 to 70 mg (Fig. 10c), conversion and yield increased simultaneously. Increasing catalyst content to 100 mg, the maximum of DMF yield of 99% was achieved after 4 h reaction. Further increasing catalyst amount to 120 mg, the changes of conversion and yield was not obvious, indicating the catalyst content of 100 mg was sufficient for HMF hydrogenolysis. The influence of solvent was also investigated and the results was shown in Fig. 10d. When ethanol was used as the solvent, only 5.1% DMF yield was achieved. The lower DMF yield could be attributed to the etherification between HMF and ethanol [31]. Because of the less steric effect of ethanol with a shorter chain, the etherification was a major reaction, which competed with hydrogenolysis, leading to the high conversion of HMF, but the low yield of DMF. When THF and 1,4-dioxane were used solvents, the yield of DMF was 87% and 92.6%, respectively. When 2-propanol was used reaction solvents, the yield of DMF was 99%. The etherification between HMF and 2-propanol was also found, but the high DMF yield was achieved, indicating that the relatively weak etherification between HMF and 2-propanol promoted the hydrogenolysis of HMF, as revealed in our previous work [53]. To understand the possible reaction path, the content changes of reactant, intermediates and products with reaction time over reduced NiZn-450 catalyst was analyzed by the GC (Fig. S5) and GC-MS (Fig. S6). As expected, the feed HMF decreased and product DMF increased gradually with the reaction time. It was noteworthy that the 5-MF intermediate increased from 0-2 h and the yield reached the highest value of 16.1% at 2 h, then the yield gradually decreased until reaching a negligible level after 4 h. This suggested that 5-MF was the main intermediate of HMF hydrogenolysis reaction. To further confirm this result, 5-MF and DHMF were used as the reactants for HMF hydrogenolysis, respectively (Table S2). It was found that when 5-MF was used, DMF yield was 98.5%. But when DHMF was used, DMF yield was only 5.1%. The results further evidenced that 5-MF was the intermediate of the reaction. According to the above results and related literature [54], reaction path was proposed in Scheme 2. Because NiZn alloy in reduced NiZn-450 catalyst had strong C-O hydrogenolysis ability, HMF was firstly deoxygenated into 5-MF instead of DHMF. Then, formed 5-MF was further hydrogenated to 5-MFA, which was the substance producing DMF. Finally, the reusability of reduced NiZn-450 catalyst for HMF hydrogenolysis was tested at 180 °C for 2 h (Fig. 11 ). In the stability experiment, the recycled catalyst was directly used without pre-reduction again for the next run. The results showed that the reduced NiZn-450 catalyst maintained a stable DMF yield (>58%) for 9 times reuse. Further reusing to 11 times, the yield of DMF showed a slight decrease, which demonstrated the potential industry use of Ni/ZnO. For verify the structure stability of the catalyst, the hot filtration test was conducted (Fig. S7). HMF conversion after the catalyst separation remained constant, which indicated that the reaction did not continue, meaning no Ni loss into the reaction solution. XRD patterns (Fig. S8) of the fresh and spent catalyst were almost the same, and ICP-AES analysis (Table. S3) of the spent catalyst showed that there was no loss of metal Ni. The above results showed that the reduced NiZn-450 catalyst exhibited an outstanding stability. 4 Conclusion In this study, the co-precipitation method was used for the preparation of the reduced NiZn-CT (CT=350, 450, 550 and 650 °C) catalyst with flower-like morphology and uniform particle sizes (∼5 μm). The H2-TPR and Raman characterizations revealed that the strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) between Ni and ZnO was generated by calcination and it was further strengthened by increasing calcination temperature. XRD, TEM and XPS characterizations illustrated that Zn was introduced into Ni lattice forming NiZn alloy and the proportion of NiZn alloy increased with the elevation of calcination temperature. NH3-TPD, H2-TPD and reaction experiments suggested that the formed NiZn alloy had high C-O hydrogenolysis ability. And the synergistic effect between the hydrogenation on Ni and the C-O hydrogenolysis on NiZn alloy is essential for Ni/ZnO catalyst. This synergistic effect was originated from the SMSI between Ni and ZnO, which can be conveniently regulated by controlling the calcination temperature. By this way, the as-prepared reduced NiZn-450 catalyst exhibited excellent performance for HMF hydrogenolysis reaction. The highest 99% yield of DMF was obtained at 180 oC for 4 h under 2 MPa H2. More importantly, this catalyst exhibited an outstanding stability for reusing 9 times. This work provided an efficient NiZn system for HMF hydrogenolysis to DMF and showed potential application for the production of liquid fuels from biomass platform molecules. coredata.dc:description: The transformation of biomass to liquid fuels and chemicals is of great interests. Herein, a series of reduced NiZn-CT (CT represents calcination temperature) catalysts with flower-like morphology and uniform particle sizes were prepared by co-precipitation method and used for hydrogenolysis of 5-hydroxymethylfural (HMF) to 2,5-dimethyfuran (DMF). The characterizations evidenced the formation of NiZn alloy phase in the catalysts through the strong metal-support interaction (SMSI), which had high C-O hydrogenolysis ability. The synergy of hydrogenation and C-O hydrogenolysis is essential for HMF to DMF, and we surprisingly found that this synergistic effect can be achieved just by controlling calcination temperature to regulated SMSI between Ni and ZnO. By this way, 99% DMF yield was gained at 180 °C for 4 h under 2 MPa H2 over reduced NiZn-450 catalyst. More importantly, the active centers of this Ni/ZnO catalyst exhibited outstanding stability. There was no significant decrease in activity after reusing 9 times. The current research provided an easy-made catalytic system for HMF hydrogenolysis.
coredata.dc:title: Efficient conversion of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 2,5-dimethylfuran by the rational design of NiZn catalysts
